General/Patient Text:
More tests are not always  good for your health,
see these links: [[more info 1; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8c7qTsVVxXw]]
[[more info 2; https://choosingwiselycanada.org/]]
[[more info 3; https://choosingwiselycanada.org/perspective/cwc-goes-mobile/]]

as we age,testing for cancer or other diseases can cause more harm than good
It depends on your overall health,speak to your provider

if sexually active                                                                                                                                                                          testing for stis includes: 
women :a pelvic exam or a urine test + blood tests. 
men: urine test + blood tests
urine test tests for chlamydia and gonorrhea 
test done by pelvic exam in women is for chlamydia and gonorrhea
blood tests: recommended to include HIV, syphilis, Hepatitis B, some include Hepatitis C

if risks                                                                                                                                                                                             testing for stis includes: 
women :a pelvic exam or a urine test + blood tests. 
men: urine test + blood tests
urine test tests for chlamydia and gonorrhea 
test done by pelvic exam in women is for chlamydia and gonorrhea
blood tests: recommended to include HIV, syphilis, Hepatitis B, some include Hepatitis C

mammogram is an xray of your breasts
Radiation has been cut back to a very [[small dose; https://www.cancer.org/cancer/breast-cancer/screening-tests-and-early-detection/mammograms/mammogram-basics.html/]]
Done every 2 years age 50 to 74

blood test to see if you are immune (protected) against rubella(german measles) 
if you are non immune you may become infected with rubella during a pregnancy
which could cause birth defects.

women age 21 or 25 to age 69
Requires a pelvic exam by your health provider.
 A brush is used to collect cells from the cervix
to measure different types of fat in your blood( good and bad cholesterol and triglycerides)
to measure different types of fat in your blood( good and bad cholesterol and triglycerides)

to measure blood sugar level if you are at risk for diabetes
shows  if you are diabetic, pre-diabetic or normal.

Sometimes called the "poop test". 
You collect small sample of stool(feces) at home which is processed in a lab.
If blood is detected a colonoscopy is recommended to detect if there is cancer
[[more info; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/colorectal/screening/?region=on#ixzz4vIhpstWx/]]
(Flexible sigmoidoscopy is another test rarely available for cancer screening)

The MOCA (Montreal Cognitive Assesement) or MMSE (Mini-Mental State Examination)
 are tests given to patients who may have memory problems. 
Each is a series of questions and takes around 10-15 minutes

If risk factors                                                                                                                                                                                               An x-ray detector scans your spine and hip.
 You receive a very small amount of radiation 
 approximately the same amount you are exposed to if you fly from Toronto to Vancouver.
[[More info; http://www.osteoporosis.ca/osteoporosis-and-you/diagnosis/testing/]]

for eveeryone                                                                                                                                                                                                An x-ray detector scans your spine and hip.
 You receive a very small amount of radiation 
 approximately the same amount you are exposed to if you fly from Toronto to Vancouver.
[[More info; http://www.osteoporosis.ca/osteoporosis-and-you/diagnosis/testing/]]

To detect lung cancer.
An x-ray machine scans the lungs
It uses low doses of radiation to make a series of  pictures of the lungs.
This is not available in most locations yet, speak to your provider.

Test: heart risk score (Issa please put this right after cholesterol blood test)
General/Patient Text:
your provider uses your [[age , sex , other risk factors; https://myhealth.alberta.ca/Alberta/Pages/Heart-Disease-Risk-Calculator.aspx]]: to measure your risk of having a heart attack.

[[Other calculator; http://chd.bestsciencemedicine.com/calc2.html]]
